title: 107_s1656
content: The Act may be cited as the "Veterans Benefits Administration Improvement Act of 2001". The Veterans Benefits Administration is responsible for processing veterans' compensation and pension claims accurately and timely. Concerns have been raised about the accuracy of claims processing, with new measurements showing lower accuracy rates than previously reported. Adequate training for claims adjudicators is crucial as the Administration faces potential workforce reductions. The Veterans Benefits Administration needs to take aggressive steps to ensure timely and accurate processing of veterans' claims to avoid delays in providing compensation and pension benefits. In 2001, the expected appeals processing time was 621 days, and the backlog of pending work was 533,029 claims. Improvement of processing of veterans benefits claims. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a plan for improving claims processing within 90 days of this Act. The plan includes mechanisms for better training of adjudicators, enhancing employee accountability, and improving data collection to reduce errors in claims adjudications. The plan for improving claims processing includes mechanisms for training adjudicators, addressing common impairments in disability claims, evaluating the impact of training systems, setting quantifiable goals, and consulting with veterans organizations. The plan will be implemented 60 days after submission. The Secretary will implement the plan for improving claims processing 60 days after submission. The plan may be modified with proper notification to relevant committees. Reports on plan implementation will be submitted every six months, assessing goal achievement. Funding will be provided for plan execution. The Secretary will implement the plan for improving claims processing within 60 days of submission, with reports assessing goal achievement every six months. Funding for plan execution will come from the Veterans Benefits Administration budget.
